pages.name: Compliance

elements.name: terra_compliance
elements.title: We need to determine if the addition of your service to the Terra system boundary constitutes a Significant Change. Select all of the below that apply. Please note that not all of these things immediately identify your service as requiring a Significant Change, but may prompt us to do a deeper dive with you to make that determination. Your service…

choices.text: Uses a new third-party application (communicates or shares data with in any way)
Uses an existing, already-approved third-party application but in a new way that sends research data or user PII to it
Is hosted on a cloud infrastructure type that has never been used in Terra
Introduces NEW functionality to Terra (this functionality is not a logical expansion of existing functionality)
Is being migrated from being hosted on one type of infrastructure to another (e.g., GAE to GKE)
Introduces a new User Interface
Changes the way that Terra does authentication or authorization
Has an impactful deviation from the New Service Production Readiness Checklist

pages.title: Compliance
pages.description: You are submitting this questionnaire for a service that needs to be part of the Terra system boundary. Terra is compliant with HIPAA and the NIST 800-53 Rev 5 information security control framework as a Moderate impact system. Your service must uphold all of these requirements, which can be done by following the New Service Production Readiness Checklist.

pages.title: Privacy
pages.description: Terra is compliant with HIPAA and the NIST 800-53 Rev 5 information security control framework, both of which require privacy controls. Broad wears two hats when it comes to data privacy. For data that we collect directly from the Terra user about the Terra user, we are a “Data Controller.” For data that Terra users bring to the system of their own accord, e.g., research data, we are a “Data Processor.” Our responsibilities for each role are different. The below questions are focused on our role as a Data Controller, so we are asking them in scope of data that we directly collect from Terra users about the Terra user. We are not asking about research data.

elements.name: Security tools
elements.title: Please select applicable items

choices.text: We are currently using SourceClear or similar tools for downstream dependency/3rd party component management
We are currently using git-secrets in our repository
We are currently using Vault/Secret Manager to store our secrets
We are currently using Codacy, SonarCloud or similar tools for security static code analysis
We are currently using Trivy or similar tools to scan our Docker images
Our service is currently scanned weekly/monthly via ZAP or similar tools

elements.name: JiraProject
elements.title: Track all security actions by creating a Jira ticket in your board.
elements.description: Please add the KEY of your Jira project. For example: ATP
elements.requiredErrorText: Please add the KEY of your JIRA project. It should contain characters and numbers.

validators.text: It should contain characters and numbers.

elements.name: Ticket_Description
elements.title: Add actions to your ticket:

choices.value: You must use git-secrets to prevent accidental commit of secrets to source code repository.
You must use SourceClear or similar tools for downstream dependency/3rd  party component management. Ask AppSec team to add your repo.
You must use security tools to scan your Docker images. Ask AppSec team to help you setup this tool.
Your service must be scanned weekly/mothly via SAST tools. Ask AppSec team to help you setup this tool.
You should only store secrets in Vault, Google Secret Manager to store the secrets. Reach out to AppSec and DevOps team to help you with setup.
You should use Codacy, SonarCloud or similar tools for security static code analysis. Ask AppSec team to help you setup this tool.
Only collect the minimum-necessary PII from users. Document where such PII is stored.
Have a documented process for deleting PII if/when required.
Allow users to view all PII about them that is stored by the system. Allow users to edit/modify such PII at will or by request.

elements.name: Alert-general
elements.html: The AppSec team will reach you out for the initial security discussion. This is basically a Threat Modeling and Security Architecture Review session. The main purpose of the meeting is for us to take an iterative, recursive look at the architecture and design of a new service/system.

elements.name: Alert-Sourceclear
elements.html: You must use SourceClear for downstream dependency/3rd party component management. Ask AppSec team to add your repo.

elements.name: Alert-Trivy
elements.html: You must use Trivy to scan your Docker images. Ask AppSec team to help you setup this tool.

elements.name: Alert-ZAP
elements.html: Your service must be scanned weekly/mothly via SAST tools. Ask AppSec team to help you setup this tool.

elements.name: Alert-gitsecrets
elements.html: You must use git-secrets to prevent accidental commit of secrets to source code repository.

elements.name: Alert-vault
elements.html: You should only store secrets in Vault, Google Secret Manager to store the secrets. Reach out to AppSec and DevOps team to help you with setup.

elements.name: Alert-codacy
elements.html: You should use Codacy, SonarCloud or similar tools for security static code analysis. Reach out to Appsec team to set it up for your repository.

elements.name: Alert-pii
elements.html: Only collect the minimum-necessary PII from users. Document where such PII is stored.

elements.name: Alert-coprocess_data_deletiondacy
elements.html: Have a documented process for deleting PII if/when required.

elements.name: Alert-View_edit_data_user_option
elements.html: Allow users to view all PII about them that is stored by the system. Allow users to edit/modify such PII at will or by request.
